doc.title: EVERCORE ISI
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Pay Dirt A Look at Mgmt. Comp Across Our CoveragePay Dirt A Look at Mgmt. Comp Across Our Coverage_2025-08-29

passages.text: With proxies and executive pay in the headlines, we are updating our annual note on executive pay across our coverage universe. This report focuses on management compensation design, short- term and long- term drivers, executive pay mix, and their compensation target/performance history. Here are some of the highlights of our key findings:

CVS: discloses forward- looking EPS targets, with LT incentives ( \(\sim 76\%\) of CEO comp, \(50 - 80\%\) of NEO comp) heavily EPS- driven, and recent PSU awards showing payouts above threshold in 2022/23 but below in 2024, and 2025 target above expectations given they were set in FY'23 IQV is also a rarity in that it discloses forward- looking EPS targets for its management team payouts o For 2025: the threshold is \(11.82\) (vs. St at \(11.87\) ) and 2026 set at \(12.55\) (vs. St at \(12.88\) ) Short- term bonus drivers have a wider variety of performance metrics (most popular operating income/EBITDA, though some variation by subsector) vs. long- term compensation o E.g. Dental and clinical more focused on revenue growth Drug distributor and CRO executives receive the majority of their compensation from long- term, heavily EPS- driven incentives, while dental executive pay plans show more variation but commonly include revenue, EPS, and TSR metrics, and over \(68\%\) of drug store executive compensation is long- term and EPS- focused. WAY, LH, IQV, and ALGN paid their CEOs more in long- term incentives vs other forms of comp DOCS, IQV, CVS, and CRL paid their NEOs more in long- term incentives vs other forms of comp In addition, there is sometimes a mix between individual and firm performance, with for example, ICLR's ST incentive comp \(100\%\) dependent on individual performance, and HSIC placing a \(40\%\) weight
Continue inside for more details on each company

Please see the analyst certification and important disclosures on page 18 of this report. Evercore ISI and affiliates do and seek to do business with companies covered in its research reports. Investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. © 2025. Evercore Group L.L.C. All rights reserved.
Short- term goals tend to focus on profitability while long- term goals include growth, relative TSR, and cultural goals
To get a better sense of what drives executive compensation across our coverage and determine how aligned mgmt. teams are with shareholders, we are updating our annual mgmt. comp analysis
Senior executive compensation is typically composed of three major elements: base salary (cash), short- term incentives (bonuses), and long- term incentives (equity- based awards)

While short- term goals are typically centered on profitability metrics, such as AOI, adjusted EPS, and adjusted EBITDA, long- term goals more often encompass growth indicators, relative TSR, efficiency targets, and cultural objectives
WAY, LH, IQV, and ALGN paid their CEOs more in long- term incentives vs other forms of comp according to their respective most recent DEF 14A
DOCS, IQV, CVS, and CRL paid their NEOs more in long- term incentives vs other forms of comp
Highest % of PSUs/MSUs
HSIC: \(\sim 66\%\) of CEO compensation & DOCS: \(\sim 70\%\) of NEO compensation
In addition, there is sometimes a mix between individual and firm performance
For example, ICLR's ST incentive is \(100\%\) dependent on individual performance, and HSIC placing a \(40\%\) weight
Short-Term Bonus Drivers - Biggest Weight to Op Income/Rev. across Coverage

Revenue, Adj. EPS, and Operating Income were the biggest drivers of annual bonuses for NEOs last fiscal yearDrug StoresCompanyRevenueAdj. EPSAdj. 2022 PSUs vest \(200\%\) w/ EPS exceeding maximum \((\) 8.84 vs. \(\) 8.75)\(- PSUs to be certified in 2025 following 3YR performance period2023 PSUs vest \(100\%\) w/ EPS at target \((\) 8.99 vs. \(\) 8.98- \(\) 9.09)\(- PSUs to be certified in 2025 following 3YR performance period2024 PSU Adjusted EPS of\) \ \(5.48\) which was below the threshold level required to achieve a payout \((\) 8.85)FY25 management targets are above current consensus EPS estimates given that they were set in 2023
Management is targeting \(10\%\) annual EPS growth from FY24 to FY26 (threshold minimum of \(6.2\%\) )Implies 2025E target EPS of \(\) 12.24\(vs. street estimates of\) \ \(11.87\)
Most names under our coverage do not disclose PSU targets for outyears, mainly for competitive reasons
All PSUs Follow 3-Year Cliff Vesting
Source: Company Filings

Overall, while operating income is the main driver of ST bonus payments, EPS is a much bigger driver for LT comp. CVS also maintains turnaround operating metrics from each segment which started in 2024 Executive compensation is highly weighted towards LT incentives, which make up \(\sim 76\%\) of CEO comp and \(\sim 50 - 80\%\) of NEO comp
LT metrics are less meaningful given pending Sycamore acquisition

Drug StoresGrant YearCompanyPerformance Metric2019202020212022202320242025CVSYR3 Adj. EPS100%100%100%100%100%70%70%Percentage of Medicare members in 4+ Star-rated plans—————10%10%Percentage of Commercial members on CVS Cost/Vantage—————10%10%Percentage of unique customers with 2+ CVS Health offerings—————10%10%
Source: Company Filings
All PSUs Follow 3-Year Cliff Vesting
Source: Company Filings
DGX's ST goals are heavily weighted toward Revenue \((40\%)\) and Adj. EPS \((40\%)\) , while 2024 LT incentives are led by 3YR Revenue CAGR \((50\%)\) , with ROIC \((30\%)\) and TSR \((20\%)\)

LH's ST plan is evenly split between Revenue and Adj Operating Income (plus modifiers for ESG and individual performance) while LT incentives remain heavily focused on EPS \((70\%)\) , with Revenue \((30\%)\) also included
Executive pay is primarily LT- driven, comprising \(\sim 78 - 80\%\) of CEO comp and \(\sim 63 - 65\%\) of NEO comp, consistent with strong weighting toward long- term financial metrics.

LabsGrant YearCompanyPerformance Metric2019202020212022202320242025DGX3YR Revenue CAGR50%50%35%35%50%50%—3YR Average ROIC50%50%30%30%30%30%—3YR Relative TSR——20%20%20%20%—3YR Cumulative COVID Revenue——15%15%———Revenues——————35%Adjusted Diluted EPS——————45%LH3YR EPS70%70%70%70%70%7070%3YR Revenue30%30%30%30%30%3030%

All PSUs Follow 3-Year Cliff Vesting

CRL Balances revenue/op income ST targets with longer-term 100% comp focused on EPS growth & TSR ICLR Compensation mix for performance metrics were not disclosed entirely, ST is largely focused on individual 75% performance ratings LT comp has a years of service component IQV ST incentives target Revenue/Profit \((52\%)\) , FCF \((11\%)\) and multiple categories including Leadership/ESG and Operational/Strategic metrics \((10 - 15\%\) each), while LT incentives focus on 3YR EPS Growth and Relative TSR FTRE ST plan is split between Net New Business and Adj. EBITDA Margin, while LT incentives focus on Revenue Growth and EBITDA CRO executive pay is heavily LT-weighted, comprising \(\sim 79 - 80\%\) of CEO compensation and \(\sim 65 - 77\%\) of NEO pay (ex. FTRE), with most plans anchored in EPS, TSR, and rev/profitability growth

Factor, not a weight Source: Company Filings
Long- term incentives make up \(90\% +\) of senior executive compensation package (no LT target breakdown published)

Similar to WAY, long term incentives account for \(>70\%\) of NEO comp mix In FY'25, CEO received a grant of RSUs that the compensation committee determined was appropriately valued for his role. The NEOs, other than CEO and CFO, participated in an annual equity refresh program that is generally available to all eligible employees. The determination to not to include the CEO and CFO in the equity refresh program was based on the compensation committee's determination that each of their existing equity holdings and other new equity grants were sufficient to align their interests with stockholders' interests for fiscal year 2025.
HCITGrant YearCompanyPerformance Metric2019202020212022202320242025DOCSTotal Revenue—————50.0%50.0%Adj. EBITDA—————50.0%50.0%
Which of Our Companies Pay Executives the Most in Stock?
DOCS, IQV, CVS, and CRL paid their NEOs more in stock vs other forms of comp
Source: Company Filings

In corporate performance- based compensation- especially in incentive plans for executives or employees- some companies define specific targets or performance goals that must be met to trigger a bonus payout (though they are less useful with significant executive and/or strategy changes).
The payout threshold is the minimum performance level that must be achieved for any payout to occur under the plan. If a company's performance falls below this threshold, no bonus is awarded.
Target: the expected or planned performance level (often a \(100\%\) payout)
Starting with the labs:
Lab executive comp increased in 2024 due to strong performance in 2024 with DGX hitting all metrics and LH almost all

Evercore ISI's recommendations are based on a stock's total forecasted return over the next 12 months. Total forecasted return is equal to the expected percentage price return plus gross dividend yield. We divide our stocks under coverage into three primary ratings categories, with the following return guidelines:
Outperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be greater than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.
In Line- the total forecasted return is expected to be in line with the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.
Underperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be less than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.

Coverage Suspended- the rating and target price have been removed pursuant to Evercore ISI policy when Evercore is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving this company and in certain other circumstances.

Rating Suspended- Evercore ISI has suspended the rating and target price for this stock because there is not sufficient fundamental basis for determining, or there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints around publishing, a rating or target price. The previous rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this company and should not be relied upon.
\*Prior to October 10, 2015, the "Coverage Suspended" and "Rating Suspended" categories were included in the category "Suspended."

FINRA requires that members who use a ratings system with terms other than "Buy," "Hold/Neutral" and "Sell" to equate their own ratings to these categories. For this purpose, and in the Evercore ISI ratings distribution below, our Outperform, In Line, and Underperform ratings can be equated to Buy, Hold and Sell, respectively.
Evercore ISI rating (as of 08/29/2025)
